Routes

Gjøvik area with Kapp Milkfactory, Stenberg, Eiktunet and finishing with multiple historical places in Gjøvik

Starting in Gjøvik with first stop at Kapp Milkfactory, we then travel to Stenberg farm, Eiktunet, Hovdetoppen, and continue back to Gjøvik citycenter to end the route with Vitensenteret, Holmen Brænderi and Gjøvik Gård.

Estimated time: 7 hours.


Image gallery

More information

Kapp Milkfactory was Nestlés first factory for production of unsweetned condensed milk, you also get to see historical pieces from the stoneage, vikingera, as well as other local history up untill modern times with environment issues.
Stenberg farm was the home of Lauritz Weidemann, a judge and politician which took part in writing the norwegian constitution at Eidsvoll Verk in 1814.
Eiktunet is a great viewpoint over Gjøvik and surrounding areas. Hovdetoppen is another great viewpoint over Gjøvik, and here lies the ruins of the restaurant from 1928, this restaurant burned down in 1964.
Holmen Brænderi produced glass in the 19th century, here you can see old glass items displayed from this time, while at Vitensenteret we offer activities and experiments within science, technology and maths.
Last we will stop by Gjøvik Gård, this was the home of Caspar Kauffeldt, the owner of Holmen Brænderi, this farm in the middle of Gjøvik citycenter is an important part of Gjøviks history.

Lillehammer area with Maihaugen, Norwegian Olympic Museum, The Norwegian Road Museum

A customizable route in the Lillehammer area, where the standard route visits Maihaugen, Norwegian Olympic Museum, Sigrud Undseths house, The Norwegian Road Museum and Lillehammer Art Museum.

Estimated time: 8 hours.


Image gallery

More information

This tour is customizable since multiple interest points are close to eachother, Maihaugen and the Norwegian Olympic Museum are at the same place and can be included or excluded as you like.
The Norwegian Road Museum are located at the Hunderfossen family park, where you can spend the rest of the day if you are interested in that.

Hamar area with Norwegian Enginehistoric Museum, Løiten Brænderi and multiple museums and locations in Hamar.

A route in the Hamar area, where we stop by Emigration museum, Norwegian Enginehistoric Museum, Løiten Brænderi, Kirsten Flagstad Museum, Norwegian Railway Museum and end up at the lovely Domkirkeodden, where the ruins of 12th century Hamardomen lies.

Estimated time: 7 hours.


Image gallery

More information

We start off with a short stop at Vikingskipet, Olympic arena, located at the shore of Mjøsa. We then continue to the Emigration Museum in Ottestad, right outside Hamar, here you learn about the history of the large emigration from Norway between 1825 and now.
We then stop by Norwegian Enginehistoric Museum located in Stange, here you find an unique collection of the evolution of machines and engines in Norway through the ages. After that we head on to Løiten Brænderi, a destilation company specializing in aquevit, formed in 1874. Here you can learn about the destilation history of Norway.
After that we head back towards Hamar, where our first stop is at Kirsten Flagstad Museum, where you can learn about her life and career. We then head on to the Norwegian Railway Museum, this is the official museum documenting Norwegian Railway history.
Last we stop at Domkirkeodden, here lies the ruins of Hamardomen and remnants of Bispeborgen, from the 12th and 13th century. In june a Medievil festival is held here, and there are lots to see.

Eidsvoll area with Bodin Ironsmith, Mjøssamlingen - Mjøsa Maritime Museum, Eidsvoll Occupation Museum and the 1814 Museum.

We start with a stop at the Bodin Ironsmith, continue to Mjøssamlingen the Maritime Museum for Mjøsa, then onto Eidsvoll Eidsvoll Bygdetun with the Occupation Museum, then we end up at Eidsvollbygningen with the 1814 museum.

Estimated time: 6 hours.


Image gallery

More information

Bodin Ironsmith started up in 1880, it was at a time 22 employes in the smith, but the need of local smiths declined in the 20th century, but it kept being an important provider of tools for the local timberbuisness untill 1960s when it shut down. We then stop at Mjøssamlingen, the Maritime Museum where you can see boats and parts of boats displayed from the history of Mjøsas rich history.
We then head on to Eidsvoll Bygdetun, here we offer lots of options, being one of Norways larges courtyards with 29 buildings, including a convenience store from 1880 and assorted farm buildings from the 19th century, here you also find the Occupation Museum.
We end the route at the Eidsvollbygningen with the 1814 Museum, an important part of Norways history lays here, as this was the place the Norwegian constitution from 1814 was written.

Gjøvik to Lillehammer, via Snartumbrua, Høgfallet and Flokofallet

A full days route to travel from Gjøvik to Lillehammer, experiencing some stunning scenery and norwegian nature.

Estimated time: 8 hours.


Image gallery

More information

On this route you get to see the 200 year old Snartumbridge, said to be the source of the fairytale "Three Billy Goats Gruff", we also stop by 2 lovely waterfalls, Høgfallet and Flokofallet on our way to Lillehammer.
This route is one of the more demanding routes, since it has 1100 heightmeters climb in total, but it's still strongly recommended.

Gjøvik to Hamar, via Mjøskastellet and option for Snartumbrua, Høgfallet and Helgøya Climbing Park

A full days route to travel from Gjøvik to Hamar, this route can also offer to stop by Snartumbrua, Høgfallet and Helgøya Climbing Park, this route offer stunning scenery and historical locations.

Estimated time: 10 hours.


Image gallery

More information

This route stops at Mjøskastellet, the ruins of a 13th century citadel. The little island are accessable by foot in the spring, but boat will be available for the rest of the season.
We also offer the options to visit Snartumbrua and Høgfallet in the Redalen-Snertingdal area, Snartumbridge is a 200 year old bridge, said to be the source of the fairytale "Three Billy Goats Gruff".
You can also stop at Helgøya Climbing Park, but we recommend visiting this on a seperate day, since you can spend several hours here.
This route can be one of the more demanding routes, since with all options it has 1450 heightmeters climb in total, but it's still strongly recommended.

Gjøvik to Eidsvoll, via St. Pauls mine and Feiring Iron extraction.

This route from Gjøvik to Eidsvoll stops by St. Pauls mine and Feiring Iron extraction. St. Pauls mine was active for several hundred years and was an important part of Carsten Ankers ironworks in both Feiring and Eidsvoll.

Estimated time: 8 hours.


Image gallery

More information

St. Pauls mine was established in 1628 and was the main source of iron for Carsten Ankers ironworks, it has been made available to the public. Feiring Iron extraction close by was one of two ironworks that Carsten Anker owned, this was in use for a short period in the 19th century.
This route has a steep climb from the mainroad up to St. Pauls mine, we can also offer this route without the stop by St. Pauls mine and Feiring Iron extraction. But we would recommend including these stops.

Lillehammer to Hamar, via Mjøskastellet and option for Helgøya Climbing Park

A full days route to travel from Lillehammer to Hamar, most of the route goes along the shore of Mjøsa, with possibility for 2 stops on the way.

Estimated time: 9 hours.


Image gallery

More information

For this route we stop at Mjøskastellet, the ruins of a 13th century citadel. The little island are accessable by foot in the spring, but boat will be available for the rest of the season.
We also offer the option to stop by Helgøya Climbing Park, but we recommend visiting this on a seperate day, since you can spend several hours here.

Hamar to Eidsvoll, via Mjøssamlingen - Mjøsa Maritime Museum

This is a scenic route where most of the trip goes along the shore of Mjøsa, we stop by Mjøssamlingen, which is Mjøsas Maritime Museum, where you can experience some of Mjøsas rich history.

Estimated time: 6 hours.


Image gallery

More information

This is one of the easier routes between towns, it is the shortest and easiest route in regard of heightmeters. We don't have many stops along the way, but we will pass some nice views along the shore of Mjøsa where we have time to stop and take photographs.
Towards the end of the trip we stop at the Maritime Museum where you can see boats and parts of boats displayed from the history of Mjøsas rich history.

View from Eiktunet
